results.title: Somebody now: 'Nobody's Children' seven years on
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), David Goldie and Christopher McCullough
results.brief_description: This film follows on from Nobody’s children”, an expose of homeless youth in inner Sydney. Seven years later, the producers have located two of the children from the original film in order to discover if things have improved for them and what impact being homeless had on their lives. The strong message that emerges is that even though the homeless person may experience a change in their socio-economic status at some point, this does not change the person they are inside. They still face the same emotional issues and burdens they had while they were homeless; unless they receive help, they will simply perpetuate the same situations over and over.

results.title: Somebody I Used To Know – Gotye ft. Kimbra
results.brief_description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube.
results.title_for_label: Somebody I Used To Know – Gotye ft. Kimbra
results.description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.
description_for_label: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. results.title: Somebodies: A YouTube Orchestra
results.brief_description: A mash-up of parodies, homages and covers of Gotye’s iconic 2011 track, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’.

constellations_other.name: Viral music videos
constellations_other.description: Gotye's 'Somebody that I used to know' was one of the internet's most viral music videos, seconded only to Queen Bey's 'Singles Ladies'.

results.title: Some women of Marrakech
results.creator_credit: Melissa L. Davies and Granada International Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disappearing world”.
An all-woman camera team gives a feminist perspective on the realities of Islamic women’s lives in Marrakech. Shows the taboos and their rights and obligations under Islamic Law from a western point of view. Includes many interviews and documents a real Islamic wedding and the traditions that are followed. Commentary by Gill Shepherd.

results.title: Some secrets should be told
results.creator_credit: Family Information Systems and Resource Communications, Jack Churchill and Henry Felt
results.brief_description: Susan Linn and her two hand puppets, Cat-a-Lion and Audrey, discuss an experience of sexual abuse that happened to Audrey’s young friend Elizabeth. They differentiate sexual abuse from normal relationships, emphasize that some secrets must be told, suggest who children might talk to, and point out that it was not the child’s fault.

results.title: Some people have to suffer
results.creator_credit: Christopher Pinney and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film documents a community’s struggle to survive in the face of government indifference and the political and financial clout of industrial developers. In 1953 the residents of Bridgeview, British Columbia, were promised sewers; following years of debate, frustration, meetings and verbiage, construction started in 1977. The film interviews some of the residents, who state their opinions frankly both to the camera and at meetings. When the film was shown at the Habitat conference in Vancouver, 1976, press coverage noted: “The Third World is merely twenty miles from the site of Habitat.” Narration: Boyce Richardson.

results.title: Some of our voices
results.brief_description: A special television program dramatising the growth of cultural centres throughout the United States. The program includes performances by Leonard Bernstein, Harry Belafonte, Marian Anderson, Pable Casals and other important performing artists from the ballet and repertory theatre. Narrated by John Forsythe.

results.title: Some like it rough
results.creator_credit: Lewis Grant Wallace, British and American Forces for the Ministry of Information and Richard Massingham
results.brief_description: An American and a British soldier meet by chance and very soon begin to argue about the relative merits, especially the “toughness” of British rugger and American gridiron football. Each man then takes part in the game played by the other man’s fellow-countrymen, and from this experiment both of them barely escape alive. Presented in a humorous fashion.

results.title: Some like it hot [DVD]
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation and Billy Wilder
results.brief_description: Two jazz musicians (played brilliantly by Jack Lemmon and Tony Curtis) witness the St. Valentine’s Day Massacre and elude their gangster pursuers by disguising themselves as women and joining an all-girl band headed for Miami. Billy Wilder and I.A.L. Diamond had no doubts that they were making the funniest film of their careers when they created this superb comedy. Marilyn Monroe plays a singer in one of her best performances ever.
